channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Harris’ plan for groceries and housing. And, the race to win 'song of the summer'
item.description: Vice President Harris is set to focus on grocery store prices and housing costs in her economic plan. And, these songs are vying for the unofficial title of "song of the summer."
item.content:encoded:
Vice President Harris is set to focus on grocery store prices and housing costs in her economic plan. And, these songs are vying for the unofficial title of "song of the summer."

(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: Examining some of the big changes coming to real estate commissions
item.description: Potentially big changes are coming to the way real estate agents are paid. Backers say it will save money in the long run, but it will likely take some time for homebuyers and sellers to adjust.
item.content:encoded: Potentially big changes are coming to the way real estate agents are paid. Backers say it will save money in the long run, but it will likely take some time for homebuyers and sellers to adjust.
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: Former President Trump is also getting his economic plans out to the voters
item.description: Republicans are pressuring Trump to focus on policy issues and not crowd sizes and personalities. At a rally in North Carolina and a news conference in New Jersey he focused on the economy.
item.content:encoded: Republicans are pressuring Trump to focus on policy issues and not crowd sizes and personalities. At a rally in North Carolina and a news conference in New Jersey he focused on the economy.
item.dc:creator: Franco Ordoñez

item.title: Harris to lay out her vision for the economy in a policy speech in Raleigh, N.C.
item.description: Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris on Friday will reveal more of her plan for the economy. She’s expected to propose cutting expenses such as health care and groceries.
item.content:encoded: Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris on Friday will reveal more of her plan for the economy. She’s expected to propose cutting expenses such as health care and groceries.
item.dc:creator: Asma Khalid

item.title: Amid Medicaid's 'unwinding,' many states work to expand health care access
item.description: States have been culling their Medicaid rolls since pandemic coverage protections expired last year. But more than a dozen states have also expanded access for lower-income people, including children.
item.content:encoded:
States have been culling their Medicaid rolls since pandemic coverage protections expired last year. But more than a dozen states have also expanded access for lower-income people, including children.

(Image credit: Makiya Seminera)
item.dc:creator: Phil Galewitz

item.title: In Florida primary, Matt Gaetz is fighting a battle over the future identity of the GOP
item.description: Gaetz is in a primary fight tied to ousted House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, the latest salvo in an ongoing war. Gaetz led that ouster. Now his district encapsulates a GOP intraparty clash that fuels dysfunction on the House floor and the campaign trail.
item.content:encoded:
Gaetz is in a primary fight tied to ousted House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, the latest salvo in an ongoing war. Gaetz led that ouster. Now his district encapsulates a GOP intraparty clash that fuels dysfunction on the House floor and the campaign trail.

(Image credit: Claudia Grisales)
item.dc:creator: Claudia Grisales

item.title: Lower inflation and rising unemployment may lead to a possible rate cut next month
item.description: Chicago Fed President Austan Goolsbee discusses with NPR's Steve Inskeep what the Federal Reserve should do next, now that inflation is trending downward.
item.content:encoded: Chicago Fed President Austan Goolsbee discusses with NPR's Steve Inskeep what the Federal Reserve should do next, now that inflation is trending downward.
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: Thailand's new prime minister renews the legacy of her father, Thaksin Shinawatra
item.description: The election of Paetongtarn Shinawatra as Thailand’s prime minister represents a remarkable back-to-the-future moment. She renews the political dynasty founded by her father, Thaksin Shinawatra.
item.content:encoded:
The election of Paetongtarn Shinawatra as Thailand’s prime minister represents a remarkable back-to-the-future moment. She renews the political dynasty founded by her father, Thaksin Shinawatra.

(Image credit: Sakchai Lalit)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Water treaty between Mexico and U.S. faces biggest test in 80 years
item.description: The water-sharing systems between Mexico and the U.S. are facing one of the biggest tests in their 80-year history after Mexico has fallen behind on billions of gallons of water deliveries.
item.content:encoded:
The water-sharing systems between Mexico and the U.S. are facing one of the biggest tests in their 80-year history after Mexico has fallen behind on billions of gallons of water deliveries.

(Image credit: Brandon Bell)
item.dc:creator: Bria Suggs

item.title: To save wild crocodiles in Australia, scientists gave them food poisoning
item.description: Freshwater crocodiles die every year in Australia from eating poisonous cane toads that humans introduced to the continent. Now scientists have found a way to teach the crocs to avoid the toxic toads.
item.content:encoded:
Freshwater crocodiles die every year in Australia from eating poisonous cane toads that humans introduced to the continent. Now scientists have found a way to teach the crocs to avoid the toxic toads.

(Image credit: Joshua Prieto)
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel
